subject: Re: [junit] Test coverage metrics reporting tool
msgSnippet: ... Although I haven t tried it myself, JesTer claims to find code that is not covered by tests. JesTer is available at:
messageBody:
John Stetic wrote:

> Hi,
>
> I'm trying to put together a test coverage metrics reporting tool, and want
> to know if anyone has tried doing this yet. (I'm sure someone has.) What I
> what to do is generate a report that shows some stats on how many classes
> have test cases and how many methods in the class under test have
> corresponding test methods. I have tried it a few different ways:
>
> 1. Just scanning through the source folder, picking up the java files and
> then checking if a ?Test.java file exists in a corresponding unit test
> folder.
>
> This approach works well if I only cared about the file coverage, but I now
> want info on the method coverage. Enter method 2.
>
> 2. Use a tool that will parse through the java source and tell me all the
> methods. I used javadoc for this, but the problem with it is that I can only
> sort through one source structure at a time, and javadoc is not so nice to
> call programmatically (it shuts down your app after it runs once).
>
> If anyone has suggestions on a better was to get info on the methods in a
> class, and other information like is the class an interface, I would love to
> hear it. Or better yet, if anyone has seen or built a tool similar to what
> I'm doing I would also love to hear about it.
>
> Thanks,
>
> John
>
>


Although I haven't tried it myself, JesTer claims to find code that is
not covered by tests.

JesTer is available at:

http://www.xpdeveloper.com/cgi-bin/wiki.cgi?JesTer
